metadata.titleEn: Spatial distribution of multi-year means (2000-2018) and temporal trends (1982-2020) of the start and end of the vegetation growing season (SOS and EOS) across the Tibetan Plateau
metadata.description: This datasets include the spatial distribution multi-year means of the SOS and EOS from 2000 to 2018, and the temporal trends of the SOS and EOS from 1982 to 1999 and 2000 to 2020 across the Tibetan Plateau. Based on AVHRR NDVI, MODIS NDVI, and EVI, four steps were used to minimize bias and noise in SOS and EOS extracted from time series of vegetation indexes. First, pixels with multiple-year average vegetation indexes lower than a threshold are regarded as areas of low or no vegetation coverage and are excluded. The pixels with weak seasonality of greenness are also excluded. Second, values of vegetation indexes contaminated by snow cover, ice, or both in winter (December–early March) are substituted with the mean of non-contaminated, high-quality vegetation indexes values during winter. Third, remaining negative vegetation indexes bias caused by clouds and aerosols in other seasons is calibrated by a Savitzky–Golay filtering technique. Finally the improved annual time series of vegetation indexes is fitted to double logistic or modified double logistic functions. Based on thresholds and inflection-point, the SOS and EOS across the Tibetan Plateau were extracted. The spatial resolution of the datasets were 250m and 1/12°. The data quality is reliable.
metadata.instructions: In .tif or ENVI standard format, can be opened and analyzed by ArcGIS or ENVI software

literatureList.titleEn: Plant phenology changes and drivers on the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau
literatureList.referenceEn: Shen, M.G., Wang, S.P., Jiang, N., Sun, J.P., Cao, R.Y., Ling, X.F., Fang, B., Zhang, L., Zhang, L.H., Xu, X.Y., Lv, W.W., Li, B.L., Sun, Q.L., Meng, F.D., Jiang, Y.H., Dorji, T., Fu, Y.S., Iler, A., Vitasse, Y., Steltzer, H., Ji, Z.M., Zhao, W.W., Piao, S.L., Fu, B.J., (2022). Plant phenology changes and drivers on the Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau. Nature Reviews Earth & Environment. doi:10.1038/s43017-022-00317-5

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collection methods for determining the start and end dates of vegetation growth seasons on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: AVHRR NDVI, MODIS NDVI, EVI datasets, minimizing bias and noise, removing pixels with no vegetation cover, low vegetation cover, or weak seasonality, replacing winter vegetation indices affected by snow or ice, correcting negative deviations using the Savitzky-Golay method, fitting annual vegetation index time series using a dual logistic or modified dual logistic function, threshold and inflection point method, spatial resolution of 250m and 1/12°.

Quantification.Question: What is the spatial resolution used in a dataset related to the Tibetan Plateau vegetation growing season?

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods based on AVHRR NDVI and MODIS NDVI compare in terms of their ability to minimize bias and noise in vegetation index time series?
Comparison.Answer: Both AVHRR NDVI and MODIS NDVI data collection methods involve a series of steps to minimize bias and noise. The process includes removing pixels with no or low vegetation cover, replacing winter vegetation index values affected by snow or ice with high-quality averages, calibrating negative biases caused by clouds and aerosols using the Savitzky-Golay method, and fitting annual vegetation index time series with double logistic or modified double logistic functions. These methods aim to provide reliable spatial and temporal patterns of vegetation growth season dates.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to spatial and temporal variations in vegetation growth season dates on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The factors contributing to spatial and temporal variations in vegetation growth season dates on the Tibetan Plateau include the methods used to minimize deviations and noise in vegetation index time series, such as eliminating pixels with low vegetation coverage or weak seasonality, replacing indices affected by snow and ice with high-quality winter indices, and calibrating negative deviations caused by clouds and aerosols. Additionally, the fitting of annual vegetation index time series using double logistic or modified double logistic functions plays a role, as well as the threshold and inflection point methods used for extracting growth season dates.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are involved in minimizing bias and noise in vegetation index time series data for extracting the start and end dates of the growing season on the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To minimize bias and noise in the vegetation index time series data, the following steps are involved: First, remove pixels corresponding to areas with no vegetation cover, low vegetation cover, or weak seasonal vegetation. Second, replace vegetation indices affected by snow, ice, or both during the winter months (December to early March) with the average of high-quality, uncontaminated winter vegetation indices. Third, correct negative deviations in vegetation indices caused by clouds and aerosols in other seasons using the Savitzky-Golay method. Finally, fit the annual vegetation index time series using a double logistic or modified double logistic function. The start and end dates of the growing season are extracted pixel by pixel using the method of thresholds and inflection points.
